This documentation is automatically generated from the source code docstrings using Sphinx autodoc.
This guide will help you install Slide Forge on your system.

Python 3.8 or higher

pip (Python package manager)

Optional: Git for cloning the repository

# Install the latest stable version
pip install slide-forge

# Or install with optional dependencies
pip install slide-forge[dev]  # Development tools
pip install slide-forge[docs]  # Documentation tools

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/marvins/slide-forge.git
cd slide-forge

# Install in development mode
pip install -e .

# Install directly from GitHub
pip install git+https://github.com/marvins/slide-forge.git
After installation, verify that Slide Forge is working correctly:

slide-forge --version
slide-forge --help

from slideforge import Slide_Forge
print("Slide Forge imported successfully!")

Slide Forge automatically installs its core dependencies:

python-pptx - PowerPoint file creation

pyparsing - LaTeX parsing

Pillow - Image processing

click - Command-line interface

For development:pip install slide-forge[dev]

Includes:

pytest (testing)

black (code formatting)

flake8 (linting)

mypy (type checking)

For documentation:pip install slide-forge[docs]

Includes:

jupyter-book

sphinx

myst-parser

ERROR: Package requires a different Python

Solution: Upgrade to Python 3.8 or higher:python3.8 -m pip install slide-forge

ERROR: Could not install packages due to an EnvironmentError

Solution: Use user installation:pip install --user slide-forge

ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'slideforge'

Solution: Check your Python path and installation:python -c "import sys; print(sys.path)"
which python
pip show slide-forge

Use PowerShell or Command Prompt

Consider using Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL)

Some LaTeX features may require MiKTeX or TeX Live

Use the built-in Python or install from Homebrew

Xcode command line tools may be required for some dependencies

Use your distributionâ€™s package manager for Python

Consider using virtual environments for isolation

For a clean installation, use a virtual environment:# Create virtual environment
python3 -m venv slide-forge-env

# Activate it
# On macOS/Linux:
source slide-forge-env/bin/activate
# On Windows:
slide-forge-env\Scripts\activate

# Install Slide Forge
pip install slide-forge

# Deactivate when done
deactivate

After successful installation:

Welcome to the official documentation for Slide Forge - a powerful tool that converts LaTeX Beamer presentations into professional PowerPoint slides.

Slide Forge is a Python library and command-line tool that transforms academic presentations from LaTeX Beamer format to PowerPoint (.pptx) format. It preserves the structure, styling, and content of your presentations while making them accessible in Microsoft PowerPoint.

ðŸŽ¯ Accurate Conversion - Maintains slide structure, titles, and content organization

ðŸŽ¨ Style Preservation - Preserves LaTeX styling and formatting in PowerPoint

ðŸ–¼ï¸ Image Support - Extracts and includes images from LaTeX presentations

ðŸ”§ Flexible Options - Multiple themes and customization options

ðŸ“š Easy Integration - Both CLI tool and Python library

ðŸš€ Fast Processing - Efficient conversion workflow

Academics who need to share LaTeX presentations with colleagues using PowerPoint

Students converting thesis presentations for job talks

Researchers preparing conference presentations

Anyone needing to bridge the LaTeX-PowerPoint gap

from slideforge import Slide_Forge

# Initialize the converter
converter = Slide_Forge()

# Convert a LaTeX Beamer presentation
success = converter.convert_file(
    "presentation.tex", 
    "presentation.pptx",
    theme="professional",
    preserve_colors=True
)

if success:
    print("Conversion successful!")

Letâ€™s get started transforming your LaTeX presentations into PowerPoint slides!
Get up and running with Slide Forge in just a few minutes!

# Basic conversion
slide-forge input.tex output.pptx

# With options
slide-forge input.tex output.pptx --theme professional --verbose

# Help
slide-forge --help

from slideforge import Slide_Forge

# Create converter instance
converter = Slide_Forge()

# Convert file
success = converter.convert_file("input.tex", "output.pptx")

if success:
    print("âœ… Conversion successful!")
else:
    print("âŒ Conversion failed")
Letâ€™s convert a sample LaTeX Beamer presentation:
slide-forge sample.tex sample.pptx --theme professional

from slideforge import Slide_Forge

converter = Slide_Forge()
success = converter.convert_file(
    "sample.tex", 
    "sample.pptx",
    theme="professional",
    preserve_colors=True,
    verbose=True
)

print(f"Conversion status: {'Success' if success else 'Failed'}")

slide-forge [OPTIONS] INPUT_FILE OUTPUT_FILE

Options:
  --theme TEXT           PowerPoint theme (default, professional, academic, minimal)
  --preserve-colors     Preserve LaTeX colors in PowerPoint
  --include-images      Include images from LaTeX
  --verbose             Enable verbose output
  --help                Show help message

converter.convert_file(
    input_file="input.tex",
    output_file="output.pptx",
    theme="professional",        # default, professional, academic, minimal
    preserve_colors=True,       # bool
    include_images=True,         # bool
    verbose=True                 # bool
)

Slide Forge offers several PowerPoint themes:

Theme

Description

Use Case

default

Clean, simple design

General purpose

professional

Corporate styling

Business presentations

academic

Academic styling

Research presentations

minimal

Minimal design

Modern, clean look

Slide titles and frames

Itemize and enumerate lists

Blocks and theorems

Text formatting (bold, italic, etc.)

Images and figures

Sections and subsections

Tables (basic support)

Mathematical equations (converted to images)

TikZ diagrams (exported as images)

Complex formatting

Animations and transitions

Embedded videos

Complex macros

Bibliography references

# Start with simple presentation
slide-forge simple.tex simple.pptx

# Then try complex ones
slide-forge complex.tex complex.pptx

# Solution: Include images flag
slide-forge input.tex output.pptx --include-images

# Solution: Enable color preservation
slide-forge input.tex output.pptx --preserve-colors

# Solution: Use verbose mode to debug
slide-forge input.tex output.pptx --verbose

Now that youâ€™ve successfully converted your first presentation:

This section contains detailed class diagrams for the Slide Forge architecture.

classDiagram
    class Slide_Forge {
        -parser: latex_parser
        -mapper: content_mapper
        -builder: powerpoint_builder
        +convert_file(latex_file: str, output_file: str) bool
        +convert_string(latex_content: str, output_file: str) bool
    }

    class LaTeX_Parser {
        +parse_file(filepath: str) Document
        +parse_string(content: str) Document
        -_extract_preamble(content: str) Metadata
        -_extract_frames(content: str) List[Frame]
        -_parse_frame(frame_content: str) Frame
    }

    class Content_Mapper {
        +map_document(document: Document) List[Slide_Structure]
        +map_frame(frame: Frame) Slide_Structure
        +map_element(element: Element) Slide_Element
        -_determine_layout(elements: List[Element]) Layout_Type
    }

    class PowerPoint_Builder {
        -presentation: Presentation
        +build_presentation(slides: List[Slide_Structure])
        +add_slide(slide: Slide_Structure)
        +save(filepath: str)
        -_create_title_slide(slide: Slide_Structure)
        -_create_content_slide(slide: Slide_Structure)
    }

    Slide_Forge --> LaTeX_Parser
    Slide_Forge --> Content_Mapper
    Slide_Forge --> PowerPoint_Builder

classDiagram
    class CLI {
        +main() None
        +parse_args() Namespace
        +convert_file(args: Namespace) int
        -_print_usage()
        -_validate_inputs(input: str, output: str) bool
    }

    class Conversion_Config {
        +input_file: str
        +output_file: str
        +theme: str
        +preserve_colors: bool
        +include_images: bool
        +verbose: bool
    }

    CLI --> Conversion_Config
    CLI --> Slide_Forge

sequenceDiagram
    participant CLI
    participant Slide_Forge
    participant LaTeX_Parser
    participant Content_Mapper
    participant PowerPoint_Builder

    CLI->>Slide_Forge: convert_file(input, output)
    Slide_Forge->>LaTeX_Parser: parse_file(input)
    LaTeX_Parser-->>Slide_Forge: Document
    Slide_Forge->>Content_Mapper: map_document(document)
    Content_Mapper-->>Slide_Forge: List[Slide_Structure]
    Slide_Forge->>PowerPoint_Builder: build_presentation(slides)
    PowerPoint_Builder->>PowerPoint_Builder: add_slide() for each slide
    PowerPoint_Builder-->>Slide_Forge: save(output)
    Slide_Forge-->>CLI: success/failure

classDiagram
    class Element_Type {
        <<enumeration>>
        text
        itemize
        block
        image
        table
        math
    }

    class Layout_Type {
        <<enumeration>>
        title_slide
        title_and_content
        section_header
        two_column
        blank
    }

    class Formatting {
        <<enumeration>>
        bold
        italic
        underline
        normal
    }

    class Slide_Element_Type {
        <<enumeration>>
        title
        bullet
        text_box
        image
        shape
        chart
    }

Separation of Concerns: Each component has a single responsibility

Modularity: Components can be tested and developed independently

Extensibility: Easy to add new parsers, mappers, or builders

Error Handling: Comprehensive error reporting and recovery

Orchestrates the conversion workflow

Manages configuration and options

Handles error reporting and logging

Parses LaTeX Beamer syntax

Extracts document structure and content

Handles LaTeX-specific features

Maps LaTeX elements to PowerPoint equivalents

Determines slide layouts and styling

Handles content transformation logic

Creates PowerPoint presentations

Manages slide layouts and formatting

Handles PowerPoint-specific features

Input: LaTeX Beamer file (.tex)

Parsing: Extract structured data (Document, Frames, Elements)

Mapping: Transform to PowerPoint structure (Slide_Structure)

Building: Create PowerPoint file (.pptx)

Output: PowerPoint presentation

New Parsers: Support different LaTeX variants or formats

Custom Mappers: Handle specialized content types

Alternative Builders: Support other output formats

Theme System: Custom styling and layouts

Classes: PascalCase with underscores (e.g., Slide_Forge, LaTeX_Parser)

Methods: snake_case (e.g., convert_file, parse_string)

Variables: snake_case (e.g., latex_file, output_file)

Constants: UPPER_SNAKE_CASE (e.g., DEFAULT_THEME)

â”‚   â””â”€â”€ metadata.py      # Metadata and related classes

Unit Tests: Test each class independently

Integration Tests: Test component interactions

End-to-End Tests: Test complete conversion workflow

Sample Files: Test with various LaTeX Beamer presentations
